reviewText: This is a damned good game.  Damned good at being multiple games, and succeeding at it.  Turn based space combat, real time space combat, text quests, real time strategy, other games would settle on a mere one or two of these, but Space Rangers HD: A War Apart is essentially the swiss army knife of space gaming.  With its consiterable polish from the previous versions, and new content, this game is a must have.  It is a perfect entry point into the game if you've never played it before.  That said, if you've played previous versions of the game, you might consiter waiting for a slight discount.  Even still, it's a bargain at any price, and will keep you entertained for literally hundreds of hours.

TL;DR: Great space 2D RPG with an arcade minigame and an RTS minigame and a whole lot of text quests for the extra retro feel. Really addictive, if you liked FTL, buy it. If you didn't, buy it anyway!

I must say, this game is great! I've had tons and tons of fun with the previous installments of this little franchise and the newest one, A War Apart is definitely the best of them. The basic gameplay which will make up most of the time you play is a top-down 2D turn-based RPG, although the turns can run smoothly without a pause unless something happens or you chose to change the course of your spaceship or the unfortunate target of your weapons. It offers a great variety of weapons, equipment and ship hulls both you and the AI can use. You can upgrade and enhance every piece of equipment you have and alter its stats using rare items called micromodules.

This variety also brings a great number of different playstiles, you can trade, complete missions for governments of different planets, be a pirate (ARRR!) and rob trading ships for money and goods, be a warrior and slay hundreds of pirates and aliens or chose any combination of those and others. Anything goes! You can also literally do nothing, just sit back and watch as the universe goes on without you, every ship pursues its own goals regardless of player's actions.

The standard quests are pretty dull, either it's a parcell delivery, guard star system, kill this one guy and so on. The quests are quite silly and can contain nice little references. But they pay you in much needed cash and some rare items, if you get lucky.

Then there are two kinds of special quests. Planetary quests bring up old-fashiond text quests which are really nice and fun, every single one of them is different and it really is a time machine that brings you a few decades back.

The other kind is the RTS strategy minigame" that lets you test your strategic skill against one to three AI armies of robots. There are resource factories you can capture and even destroy. Those can be protected by 4 kinds of deffensive turrets. The units you and the AIs control are modular robots. You can customise every single robot you make

reviewText:
Back in the day I stumbled across Space Rangers 2, played it, and totally loved it. Only after that I played Space Rangers 1, both of which I have on steam. And yeah, the older Space Ranger parts were once on steam, but for some reason they've been taken down from sales. That is if you already bought them you can still install and play them from steam.

Strictly speaking Space Rangers HD is a remake of Space Rangers 2. It started out rather similar, but with time I feel that HD has really become a new game. There is a HUGE lot of more content than in Space Rangers 2.

Pros:
-Intrinsicate and tactical space combat
-Massively varied hulls and equipment
-The general difficulty, primarily space combat, ranges from easy (the galaxy will eventually mostly fix itself) to nightmare (the galaxy is totally doomed unless you are constantly there to protect it)
-The difficulty can also be adjusted very precisely
-The galaxy is truly alive, and nothing centers around you, unless you get the power to make it so, but even then life will always go on, whether you're there to witness it or not
-Great and emotionally immersing music (this is obviously subjective, I've also seen reviews that claim the music is subpar, something I'd never agree on)
-The addition of planetary battles, black hole arcade battles and text quests makes the Space Rangers universe feel much more complete and immersive, and you're mostly not forced into either of them
-The devs are still active some 2 years after the game has been released and it is very polished, I guess I don't have to mention that this can't be taken for granted nowadays
-Interesting story and you're not forced to approach it in one single way, do whatever you feel you have to do

Cons:
-Planetary battle difficulties range from almost impossible to lose to almost impossible to win, some of the maps are so hard I don't see any casual gamer ever winning them (not without like 24 hours of practice and/or guides at least), and here you have no say in the difficulty of the maps you get, except for taking more resistant bots or more reinforcements on hard maps, which reduces your rewards
-The AI behaves mostly intelligent and acceptable, but there are some exceptions, military ships will sometimes pick their targets so badly they can't even kill one enemy before dying, and your robots in ground battles are in constant danger of committing suicide if you're not there to prevent it
-The devs thought that having ships simply shoot and destroy wares in space is a good way of keeping sectors clean, so you see something really valuable in the system, you're on your way and you see a civilian ship flying by? You can almost certainly expect it to shoot down your loot, the same counts for military ships when you fight dominators, always keep a save handy in case some of the military ships decide it's important to shoot down your most valuable drops (ships will start shooting wares after there are 7 objects in the system... which happens very fast because even the passing asteroids will easily litter 7 mineral pieces into the system)

I might've descibed the negative points in details, but don't let that fool you, the pros vastly outnumber the cons. Is it worth getting this game? If you like turn based space RPGs the answer is: Hell YES!

reviewText:
I was introduced to Space Rangers 1 by my father, we sunk approximately 100 hours into it, he was staying up at night playing it. It was such a great game at the time! Space Rangers 2 managed to keep the feel of the first one, and add a bunch of other great stuff to it! This is a game made as a shared dream, it's made with love, you just can see the devs sitting there late at night brainstorming, adding everything they think they are capable of to the game.

http://youtu.be/iWOhjtpQKHg

What you get when you buy this game:

- A world, inhabited by 5 races, a world that doesn't really need you, as it can solve most of it's problems itself, sometimes even winning the game doesn't require your input.
- A plethora of space quests: deliveries, bounty hunting, escorts, guarding a system, etc.
- Space trading, that requires you to analyze the galaxy's markets and the margins you can profit on.
- Turn-based space travel and combat, diplomacy even, there's usually several ways to resolve a conflict.
- A 2D arcade space shooter.
- Planetside RTS, around 40 different maps, 4 sides of the conflict, mech constructor, ability to take control of a mech individually in an FPS-like fashion.
- Text-based quests, ranging from solving ancient mysteries, to exploring planets, to baking pizza or running a gaming magazine.
- A lot of customization, you can improve your ship as new tech is researched and better devices are unlocked, and then improve some more by adding the artifacts, micromodules and science station upgrades.
- A simple talent system, you can also level up your followers' or space stations' talents.
- Diseases and stimulators
- Great space themed music, although the compositions added in A War Apart are not as good as the original ones.

The negative stuff:
- Older graphics can be a turn off for a lot of people.
- Most of the positive things were there before A War Apart, this rerelease just adds some more variety and feels very fan-made (and it partially is).
- More scripted situations were added, and they seemed to crash me a lot.
- Subpar A War Apart music.
- Making the pirates a third force worked out in a strange way.

A War Apart seemed rather raw to me, compared to the original SR2 and SR2: Reboot, if you can get either of those, then it's better to go for them.

Rating it 8/10 - A strange iteration of a 10/10 game, no way to get the original off Steam though, so still worth it.

reviewText:
One may be a bit suspicious that the game advertises so many features, but it does execute them very well.

First off, I recommend reading the only english speaking guide as a good primer on what settings make a good beginner game. Also, sell your starting shields (if your ship has any) because they are complete crap that takes up too much space at the beginning. Shields in this game only block percent damage, and starting shields block next to nothing. Missiles/frag cannons are very good weapons early to mid, though missiles must be manually reloaded. Finally, find a pirate base and join them for a free, VERY good ship. It doesn't matter if you don't want to go pirate, you can always go grab the ship and just fight dominaors for pirate favor/backstab them and hunt them down. Ironically the one segment of the game that is the most obviously advertised, space combat, is also the most infuriatingly obtuse to figure out without the help of a guide or google.

Starting tips aside, the trading in this game is dynamic and well done. Planets each start with governments/econmies that are geared towards importing/exporting certain goods, and events such as famines, pandemics, or a change of government will occur that shake up prices. One can make a fairly good amount of money by keeping check of the news and moving large quantities of goods in a freigher. you can own multiple ships, so if you have a fancy fighter you can just park it on the planet.

Speaking of which, in the lower left tab quests, assets, and any news blurbs you flagged are kept there for your future reference, making it easy to keep track of assets you store on different planets/stations, or where you were supposed to ship your cargo hold full of medical supplies.

Quests are offered at government centers on each planet, and are by and large FedEx delivery missions. Asking for easier/harder missions only affects the amount you earn and the amount of time to complete the delivery. You are paid whenever you complete a delivery, making it very easy to simply FedEx you way into riches (if you have the patience)

Some quests end up turning into text adventures (and are usually indicated rather obviously as not your standard delivery). Judging by the ones I've played, the text adventures are rather well done and fair. In the event of player death or failure, you are rerolled back in time to try again/give up whenever you want.

The RTS segments are somewhat simplistic, with the complexity coming in purely through how you choose to build your combat units. Simplistic doesn't mean bad however, and for the most part they were rather fun. With the glaring exception of several missions that are hellishly difficult.

What I find most attractive about the game is its sense of immersion. Events happen around the player, and it is up to them how to respond. The Coalition, Pirates, and Dominators will all launch attacks/defend star systems, other Space Rangers will fly around doing their thing, more Rangers will be recruited to expand/replace losses. Research into better technology will happen (and can be funded by the player), militaries will build new ships/garrison systems (can also be funded), and overall it gives of a good sense of Hey

Several game types all packed into one great game.

reviewText:
A really great RPG experience. The universe is huge and the new additions of the HD version make the game a lot more interesting. The game is however, nothing for graphics junkies: Spacebound action looks okay, nothing special, its perfectly playable, but dont expect much. There are also a lot of text-based quests. They are really a great and at times hilarious read if you give them a chance, often they are also really tricky and demanding.
The real strength of this game lies in its incredible strategic depth. You will have a great fun upgrading your equipment, searching for new weapons etc. If you are not a fan of this, you should reconsider, as you will spend a lot of time doing exactly that. The game also has a unique sense of humour, that however doesnt degrade the atmosphere at all (for example a quest where you have to deliver an old MS Windows Version to some planet). Combat is turn-based and in my opinion incredibly well done, as it allows for a lot of tactical possibilities, while being fast paced and satisfying aswell.
Also the world is extremely open, you can choose from five races, you can be a pirate, a merchant, a fighter, whatever you want. You can visit any planet you want, you can look for secret equipment on unpopulated planets with research probes, you can explore black holes, which throw you into an oldschool arcade shooting style world, IMO great fun.
You can defeat the different dominator races in a multitude of different ways, you can support the governments in many different ways. You can be a lone wolf, or you gather the strongest rangers you can find under your command. Theres just so many ways to play this game.
The only two drawbacks that I can think of: The pirates are somewhat overpowered if left on normal pirate aggression. I recommend tuning them down a little in the advanced difficulty settings (thats right, the game allows you to adjust the difficulty of pretty much anything in it seperately). They are more like some super-well financed, organized cyber-rampage crew, rather than a bunch of outlaws.
The second problem is that you now have to repair dominator weapons with nodes. This is on one hand really annoying, on the other hand somehow fair, because they are really, really strong.
The game has a steep, but fair learning curve and a lot of replayability value. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Note that I have never played any of the other Space Ranger games before I played this on Steam.

A truly remarkable game with many options and choices, deep and interesting mechanics and simulation with a very unique gear system. Every other coalition/pirate ship out there follows similar rules as you. Think they are being overpowered? You can do that, too! Their hull, their equipment... it is all highly varied and customizable.

In short, you start out a nobody in a galaxy with tier 1-2 gear available. You run some measly errands or try to make a profit with goods until your equipment is up to par with the latest tier currently available (increases over time up to 8, one of the wonderful things of this game) after which you can start picking fights. Note that on higher difficulties progression is VERY hard, with the coalition losing ground rapidly (because all Rangers lack the experience/gear to fight Dominators effectively until around tier 5+). The few negative complaints I have seen mostly revolve around either the lack of information when starting out (read the tips at the bottom bar!) or because they cannot win alone against 5+ ships following similar rules as yourself (doh!). But the fun part is, that there is almost always more to discover, some mechanic you did not know about, some option you did not try... Just remember the game auto-saves every time you leave a planet/station, and you can load this (bottom save) when you screw up and get your ship blown up. You know, for all those times you think you can take on that wretched pirate that tries to rob you ;)

Despite some minor issues with English, I'd still give this game the full 10/10.
Especially since it's relatively cheap, but then you don't exactly get the latest in graphics either.

reviewText:
As far as 2D space sims go, I would vote Space Rangers to be the best of all time, even better than Star Control 2.

Space Rangers offer a great variety of gameplay: combat, trading, piracy, exploration, salvaging, upgrading ship and skills, text adventures, planetary battles, arcade minigame. There is always something to do, and all playstyles blend nicely together for a complete and satisfying game experience.

This game has a living and breathing world, where every NPC has a purpose. Traders carry goods from one planet to another, pirates try to convince them to offload those goods to them, diplomats and transports fly between planets doing diplomat-y and transport-y stuff (gameplay-wise, they are either used by pirates to extort money, or fight the said pirates). There are also rangers, like yourself, who can be pirates, or traders, or warriors, and who behave accordingly. Each of these NPCs is persistent, which means they don't just disappear forever when you leave their star system. In fact, you can use the in-game search functionality to track any NPC across the galaxy, by simply typing its name (you could even play it as a stalking simulator).

I want to mention that Space Rangers have a very flexible game difficulty setting. On the lower difficulties, your enemies don't control many star systems, so you can freely fly across the galaxy, trading and completing government missions. On the highest difficulty, the enemies control most star systems, and you are left with half a dozen (or less) systems that you can visit without getting annihilated by a swarm of enemies within a minute. This adds a kind of fighting a losing war" desperation feeling

reviewText:
The main reason I am not reccomending is for two reasons. The first is that pirates and the weapons Lirecron and Esogapher are completely OVERPOWERED. After spending 60 hours in game with the best ship possible I am still UNABLE to defeat them.

As things stand the only way to combat the pirate threat since you can't engage them yourself is to fund the construction of warships. In other words you need to take it upon yourself to construct the military fleets of the ENTIRE UNIVERSE since the creators of this game had the brilliant idea of creating weapons that can shut down all of your systems.

You've created the best defensive ship in the game? A few hits from the lirecron will shut down your shields and negate your cladding.

You've got the most offensively capable ship in the game? A few hits from the lirecron will shut down your weapons radar and scanner. You are now unable to shoot weapons.

Maybe you've got the fastest hull in the game. A few hits from the lirecron will shut down your engines leaving you dead in the water for pirates to prey upon.

In my current game pirates have taken over the vast majority of coalition systems and I am powerless to stop them despite having the best ship in the game

Who's IDIOT idea was it to give the pirates a weapon that negates every possible in game advantage. This is not even mentioning the Esophager which has similar negative effects.

Furthermore the additional content is fairly horrible. It consists of a few more text adventures and a few more hulls. The new text adventures are needlessly opaque. I was trying to take the direction that would allow me to get rid of the pirates but ended up becoming their leader and helping them win against the coalition.

Pirates are the most OP faction in existence for reasons mentioned earlier. In Space Rangers 2 reboot eventually you would be able to take out entire military fleets by yourself but the advent of the Lirecron makes that impossible.

The second reason I am not reccomending this game is that the creators have nerfed all end game content. Space Rangers 2 reboot had 3 beautiful unique ships obtainable in the end game. If you enable these ships in Space Rangers HD you are unable to get achievements.

Furthermore they have nerfed all end game content. Shield generators now have a maximum of around 50-55 percent whereas in Space Rangers Reboot you could have 87 percent. The default version of the game does not include the unique ships from reboot which are infinitely better than any of the new hulls.

The third reason I am not reccomending this game is that all of the problems that existed in Space Rangers Reboot exist in Space Rangers HD.

Repair costs are still way too high and nothing is done to negate this. With end game gear expect repairs to cost 300000 credits which is a small fortune. The only means of earning enough money in the end game to offset these costs are planetary battles which is a trial in and of itself. Every time I a planetary battle mission instead of seeing it as an opportunity to earn 10+ million credits I see it as an extreme annoyance especially since so many of the maps are poorly thought out.

Good micromodules like Universe and Shell are still impossible to get leaving intact the previous crappy system of getting micromodules. Furthermore the good micromodules like Panzer and Broing have been nerfed and instead of giving 16 cladding the Space Rangers HD equivalent of the panzer now gives only 8 cladding.

Good points:

There are some good points to Space Rangers HD. I like the idea of weapon modifications. Also some of the new gear is decent like nanobrolite engines or upgraded shield generators.

I like the new bertor dominators since dominators were ridiculously easy in space rangers reboot. Now they have adequate difficulty because of the new bertors.

However in spite of some steps forward the fact that Pirates are totally game breaking is a major leap back. There are three versions of this game. Space Rangers 2, Space Rangers 2 Reboot, and Space Rangers HD. The one I would recommend is Space Rangers Reboot.

Fixing this game so that it would be the best of the three is easy. Just get rid of the Lirecron and Esophager or give the player some means of defense against these weapons. As things stand pirates are way too OP. They can shut down all of your systems relatively easily and the coalition can't stand against them without regular investments in new military vessels. These issues NEED to be fixed.

reviewText:
A blast from the past of my own childhood. I loved the entire Space Ranger series as a whole and used to play it non-stop. I loved the game so much and I still love it to this very day.

The soundtrack is simply masterful, especially the Human theme which just rings of glory and sadness at the same time. I used to spend hours just docked on any Human colony world just listening to that theme song, refusing to take off even to defend the system from Klissans, Dominators and Pirates.

Now, the game itself is based around a group of non-military volunteers called ''Rangers'' who are tasked with defending the Interstellar Coalition of Five Races (Humans, Gaal, Faeyans, Maloq and the Pelengs) from any threat that may threaten their security. The Rangers are each their own general, their own corporation or bank and can hire other Rangers to work under their command. In this game, there are tons of ways to improve your combat capabilities, and also tons of ways to just play the game. You can be a Warrior, a Mercenary, a Merchant, a Corsair or a Pirate and just play for as long as you want in a single playthrough. They're literally unlimited.

In the end, this game would probably get a 10 out of 10, but the overall lack of variation between planets and the top-down gameplay is severely lowering the score, HOWEVER, it doesn't impact on the overall game as it's still a perfect space sim of its time and for those who want to await a better one similar in style to this one, but without the top-down limitation.

Quick Summary  A Space exploration, action, RTS, Text-adventure filled space adventure. The only REALLY GOOD Space game that 1c has ever put on steam.

The Summary You know... OUT of ALL the 1c games I bought from their space fi bundle... This made it worth it. The universe revolving around you... watching as a reaper like menace is taking over your galaxy, the universe has about a million npcs floating and moving about, conducting trade, business, pirating, looting, and fighting. History is always being recorded! Watch as the galaxy news, or just NPC's converse about the recent events in either the local area, or how the Reaper menace's situation is currently going. Hear about the lastest news that the Galaxies biggest fleet was just annihiliated in an attempt to push back the aliens forces! +

Your not Commander Sheperd! Your just another speck floating around in space! Will you be a soldier aiding against this reaper menace? Or watch the galaxy slowly be consumed? It's your choice. +

Exploration is kind of fun, does feel a little dull... +

Multiple random text adventure games brought through quests, like going to prison. ++

RTS mode, though a little basic, it's still lots of fun! ++

Neutral: Soundtrack is pretty generic..?

Trade Grinding, though optional, can quickly make the game too easy. -

Conclusion? 8/10. One of my most favorite Space Sims.

reviewText:
Space Rangers is perhaps the single greatest game you have never played. Now I do not blame you for not knowing about an obscure Russion top down roguelike in space... but if you do not buy this game and play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it right this very second then I just feel sorry for you.

In the mid 2000's there was an explosion of highly creative game development that came out of Europe. S.T.A.L.K.E.R and The Witcher are the two that made it big and everyone has heard of. The other two amazing titles of the time that did not make it big were The Guild, and Space Rangers. Due to being far more niche in their appeal very few people know about the latter... which is a shame because they are fantastic.

Space Rangers truly is like 4 games in one. The main game is a top down Sci-Fi Roguelike very much akin to Star Control. If you fly into a blackhole you go into a bonus arcade stage that works much like the Maze levels in Sonic the Hedgehog. You can choose to take missions on some planets and space bases which then send you on a wild text based adventure the like of which Steve Jackson would be proud of and finally there are RTS levels where you take control of an army of Mechs and have to destroy the enemy base to capture a planet or take control of it away from the enemy faction.

This may sound like a mix of mini games splattered into a Roguelike... However, these other game types are anything buy mini. They are highly detailed, well formed, engaging with a huge amount of varied content that adds a ton of variaty to a main game that actually manages to deliver on a living universe.

If you enjoyed Star Control, Space Pirates and Zombies, Sins of a Solar Empire, X-Series, Elite or any Roguelike or Space Opera title... then you owe it to yourself to play Space Rangers.

I love in-cockpit space games too, but theres just something fun about the top driven ones. And this game is the king of the top-down space games!

reviewText:
I would rank this game absolute number 1 among all the games I played.

If you like RPG, RTS, arcades or turn-based games and never tried a mixture of all of them, then you must play this one.
This game offers everything is small portions, so if you don't like a part of it, your impression of the entire game will not be spoiled. If you hate RTS or text quests, it is entirely possible to skip all missions that offer those. If you don't like turn-based fighting, then choose a peaceful path of a trader. Alternatively, if you are down to kick some butt, just bully all pirates on your way and destroy dominators. There are countless ways to play the game and I bet anybody will find a way to enjoy it.

reviewText: What can I say about Space Rangers?\n\nWell, my first contact with the game series had been established sometime in 2003/4. I played SR1 a bit and quickly moved on to SR2, which was not an actual sequel but an update. A fact which remained true for every following sequel
date:
didn't know that at the time.

I played SR2 quite extensively over the years, one of two games to which I returned quite often, the other being GTA SA. Once I got a whiff of SR2 Reboot, English version of which trailed behind the Russian release, I grew impenitent over obtaining a copy. Finally it came around on Stardock's Impulse service where, after some proxy shenanigans, I managed to obtain a license of the aforementioned software, leading to quite a lot pleasurable game time.

Of course SR TWA was supposed to be played with burning passion as well. Burning indeed.
The game has been extensively updated (both in content and regarding technical aspects) over the years and made even more interesting. To those players who may be inclined toward this type of games.

What type of game is it, you ask, impatient reader? Well, it's an SF roguelike RPG space trader sim riddled with textual quests and packed with arcade and RTS battles. It basically covers all known game genres, with possible exception of triple x rated games, FPS shooters and sports sims. No, you can not play football in SR universe, sorry about that.

Of course not all of these components have been well executed, but that's just how the cookie crumbles. Imagine if the RTS battles didn't suck, the game would be even more attractive and demand even more time. That would just suck. You realize, something has to suck.

Pros:
- everything excluding what's listed below

Cons:
- I wish the devs had access to more resources so that they may translate ALL the game content into English, instead of having to opt for leaving a part of it out. The game is Russian centric, but instead of seeing this as something negative, one should take this fact for what it is - an excellent opportunity to learn Russian

- as it has been mentioned a number of times, RTS mode sucks. However, it's completely optional, which one doesn't get to see in modern games that often. If at all. These missions can be challenging and rather rewarding, but most of them are quite a chore due to incredibly bad controls and pathing issues

- some consider the arcade black hole mode to be bad, but I personally disagree. While arcade mode is nothing extra super special, it can be a nice way to obtain some otherwise unattainable equipment and provide a break of standard space faring. My qualm over this are possible balancing issues, since you can get quite expensive gear out of the hole fairly early in the game by investing next to nothing into it. Another thing that sucks a bit is the fact that all those weapons which are great in the hole are otherwise useless. And vice versa, so having nice end-game weapons can make the hole problematic to complete. Maybe this was intended by design, IDK really

- I can live with the game being random, however some bits are simply not random. You're practically being cheated now and againg.
Two examples:
1. some micromodules are not (to the best of my knowledge and experience) attainable from Ranger Centers. There are a few modules (Universe, Broing, Strongster (which may not be in the game anymore, not sure)) which you'll get to see on about one out of three playthroughs. In ten years playing various versions I got something like 2-3 Universe modules, Broing probably only once and Strongster definitively only once. Not nice, especially since you can regularly come across (usually) pirates having half a dozen of these
2. some dominator gear simply won't drop while using distress signal. I typically check what do they carry before engaging, usually looking for the holy grail of SR (namely the Vertix weapon fixture.) Once I find one that's type H and below 160 weight I spam that dominator with distress signals but the item in question is simply not jettisoned. I understand that obtaining such a powerful weapon too early may pose balancing issues, but that item is quite heavy and expensive to maintain, so it's really not nice to have something like that pulled on an unsuspecting Ranger. Not nice indeed

Room for expansion:
- one thing I can't understand is why (after defeating the dominators and before actually finishing the game) existing races stay friendly instead of simply having a showdown, with petty feuding, consorting and what not. That would provide for some after-game entertainment and it would be quite logical conclusion
- RTS components in actual space. Something like: I have more credits than common sense and want to render this and that system dominator/pirates/coalition proof by means of heavily armored battle stations
recommended: private combat ships and what not)"\n- a unified node account so that your Ranger node account can be used to draw required resources for all your needs
hoursPlayed: including upgrades and maintaining equipment. It seems silly and cumbersome to lug around 1200 nodes to the nearest science stations to have something upgraded. Seems almost like a bug instead of a missing feature\n\nI think that's about it. As for the sheer size of the world and content

Story and setting concerning the dominators is pretty good, most other things are quite generic.

Early in the game you do missions for governments and it's either:
Bring object A to location B, within a set amount of time.
Kill guy in ship A, last seen in system B, within a set amount of time.
Go to location B, do a text quest/puzzle.

reviewText:
Space Rangers HD is a very niche open-world turn-based space trading and combat strategy game that I think many people will find rather frustrating.  The game is improperly balanced so that the player has a very narrow path to success and a steep learning curve.  There's a lot of different ships and parts you can use, but many of them seem not to be viable and will lead to your death.   Not enough firepower?  You die.  Not fast enough?  You die.  Not earning enough income to pay off pirates or repair your ship after fighting them?  You die.   Not enough fuel make a hyperspace jump to run away?  You die.  The learning curve and narrow path to success reminds me very much of the game X3: Terran Conflict, another more-complex open-world space trading and combat game which I would recommend over this.  If you are able to find the path to success then you may enjoy these games greatly, but if you fail to find it you will die again and again without making much progress and probably give up the games without experiencing what they have to offer.

In this game you are supposed to try to control the pirate threat but you aren't powerful enough to kill pirates early in the game, only fast enough to chase them around and sustain a lot of damage fighting them only to have them land on a planet and fully repair their ship most of the time.  Before you know it the whole universe starts getting overrun by pirates and you have only been able to kill one or two strays.  You start to get jumped by more pirates than you can afford to pay off or hope to kill off, run out of money, then die.  Prepare to save and reload often in this game as that seems to be the main path to survival when you don't know what you may encounter before entering a black hole or a sector or taking a quest.  Death is going to find you, so be sure you have saved before that.

Some of the planet battles in the game are difficult and frustrating and will require many restarts in some cases before you randomly end up with the right plan and conditions that will allow you to succeed.  You can skip them if you want to as the game does have an option to do that.

There is some gaming population that will find games with narrow success conditions and an abundance of options, many of which are superfluous or serve to hide the narrow path to success fun to play.  These players enjoy overcoming difficulty and pride themselves in their ability to analyze a situation and find a way to succeed.  They will find the way to exploit weaknesses, recognize patterns, and filter out what doesn't lead to success.  They require a certain amount of failure to make victory worth achieving.  If all or even most players succeeded, then the challenge would not be great enough for them.  If this sounds like you, then you may enjoy this game.  If that doesn't sound fun to you, then you probably should pass on this one.

reviewText:
3/5 and only get it if it is on sale.

I have played this game before it went HD and I completed it without cheats back then.

It was long and tedious.
Seeing it on sale on Steam I thought to myself - gonna get it, gonna cheat it, gonna have fun again.

And I would like to point this out now - I am all against multiplayer cheaters, skill is all that should matter.
However I totally support cheating/modding in single player modes, because poeple should enjoy the game the way they like.
Fancy hardcore mode with one life? Go for it. Fancy easy mode with uber-guns and steamrolling through hordes of enemies? Go for it.

Above everything else, have fun playing the title.


Nope, not here.
Space Rangers is a very difficult game and very time consuming. Unfortunatelly quite imbalanced too.
Any attempts at using build in cheats or cheat engine will flag your game as 'cheated' and you will get no achievements, no score ranking etc.

Keeping that in mind (you might think it is not a big deal, after all) I have to warn you that by playing this game you are in for a quite of a boredom unless you get the mechanics right - and quite a lot of dying as well, so save often before engaging in space combat.


Now onto review:

Graphics: 3,5/5
It is colourful, eye candy, outdated 2006 graphic style ported into 2013 that will wear you out quickly.
Game is not bad looking and there are no graphical issues I can speak of, but it is missing the immersivenes of other space themed titles - colourful nebulas, detailed planets, cool ship graphics - it is not there, do not expect it, don't look for it, don't wait for it. What you see in your first system is all there is.

What you see in your first land battle/black hole is also all there is.

Gameplay 3/5
Planetary quests are hand drawn, text based, old school adventures of choices. They are in some parts very random and you are advised to save prior to starting one. Some of these (like this game of one pawn against 4) require few tries to complete due to random AI movements. Others require you to familiarize with quest first in order to understand it's mechanics. (A warning. Don't dig down in sex-change quest for a Peleng IF you play as a Peleng).

Planetary quests are the most difficult part of the game and the most enjoyable. Each is different and unique; this is the only part where Space Rangers really shines.

The RTS battles are sometimes simply impossible to win (you will see) and require constant activity (non-stop production and attacking) and are very crappy, but they pay quite well.

Space battles and generally things you do in space fall into 2 categories:
- making money by scavenging stuff from space/planets, performing easy quests (package delivery, get a quick ship, get all those quests and earn tons of money), or by so called trading (use trading centers to figure out best deals)
- running into or away from combat. This is where this game falls flat on it's face and moans in agony. You will need few deaths to get used to general turn-based combat system, targeting, and generally understanding why you do not do any damage.

In difference to the original game there is this pirate faction added into the title, but they are just 'meh'.
You can either bother yourself with antagonizing pirates (meaning, every system will have a hostile pirate fighters) or going against Coalition (meaning, every system will become hostile), which is just as stupid as it sounds.

There is no storyline to speak of. You are a ranger, who wants to become THE Ranger, there are some evil guys (rouge machines) that will shoot you on sight, there are some good guys (basically anyone else) that you can interact with. You either destroy the evil ones (oddly, you can join them, but it is game over with some info that you destroyed good guys) or they destroy everyone else, plain and simple. No twist, no immersion, no nothing. Just us vs them.

Unless you cheat in money(and you don't want to in HD edition, as mentioned), you will have to spend first few(or more) years of the game just getting enough to buy a decent ship and components (and by decent I mean the one that lets you fly through dominator's systems and live) and upgrade them with micromodules to the point of usefulness. The real game starts then (you will get a ton of exp/badges by the time you will be ready for combat) only for you to discover that either:
- evil ones are too strong and you will have to reconquer dozen of systems (gets very boring very soon, especially since they fight back trying to instantly recapture the system) just to get a chance to get to their homeworlds and destroy bosses
- they have been reduced to just a few systems and there is no one left to fight (game will end in next few years)

Music 1/5
I will give this poor rating for what have been done in HD edition.
In original game, music was in .dat format, you could listen to it outside of the game and with some tinkering replace the few poor track with something better. This is no longer the case in HD edition - everything is packed into pkg file.
Therefore you are forced to listen to few very good tracks and then be interrupted with few really, really crappy.
There is simply nothing you can do with that, as touching game files is out of the question.
It's either turning the music off altogether and playing it out of soundtrack (really, a soundtrack was added as a standalone?) or suffering it while you will be pulling your hairs out during some intense (and by that I mean hundreds of missiles aimed at you) space combat.


It's 2014 and steam workshop is alive and kicking, yet devs of this game are becoming increasingly paranoid about anyone who buys their stuff actually trying to get more fun out of it by cheating/modding.


As such I can't recommend HD edition to you.
Get yourself SR2:Reboot, play it, cheat the most annoying parts of it (and there are many), have fun.
You won't have much fun here, once you will understand how little profit you can make by trading/missions and see the price tag for decent equipment and how shockingly imbalanced SR really is. This game simply becomes a grind for gold way too soon and stays that way until almost the end.

Also some difficulty settings are no longer available on start - they have been moved to 'advanced settings' and using them means your score will not be posted (WTF, really?!). Yes IT IS THAT STUPID AS IT SOUNDS!


So in conclusion - there are other titles for you to play for 18€ that you will enjoy much better. This one is not worth that much money.

For less than a 5€ however you might give it a go, just don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed.

You are warned.

reviewText:
This game is basically Star Control without the charm. Game design has come a long way in 20 years, and this doesn't really stand up to the test of time.

Although trading and quests are part of the game, and mildly entertaining, the only real long-term solution is violence, which is very unsatisfying in its mechanics.

In friendly sectors, you click on a pirate ship to lay in what is supposed to be an intercept course, and set which guns to activate. What actually happens is you face away from your target while he chases you, making all your forward firing missiles take forever to double back and hit your enemy. Then, when he's at half hull, he breaks off and afterburns to a nearby planet to escape destruction, leaving you with nothing to show except a damaged hull and a bunch of empty missiles.

In hostile sectors, you get swarmed and die. And don't even mention the RTS surface battles. They should have just cut them—I thought Empire at War's planetary battles were superfluous...but boy were they a treat compared to this.

To summarize, the controls are too poor to formulate any consistent tactic, and you're forced to constantly reload to get lucky enough to kill anything. All this time, you're draining your bank account, making it about as hard to get ahead as in real life. It's possible if you're patient, just not fun.

reviewText:
Spacerangers is a simple concept of a 2D space game taken to the extreme . Don't let that minigame look fool you this game has a $60 worth of content . It has somewhat of a sandbox feel to it because you can progress through the game by fighting dominators,trading,doing quests or just being a pirate .

The main menu has a very nice custom gameplay options which you can use to make it harder or easier on yourself . Also you can get much better starting ship at the cost of some races hating you which is a risk vs reward option .

Probably the most important part of this game is just the fact that it is so visually uniqe and the soundtrack is amazing . It may not be a 3D space game but it still creates very immersive atmosphere .

There are several gameplay types that may appeal to different players . You have a turn based space combat, RTS style ground quests where game completly changes the way it plays , Text Missions for people who enjoy puzzles and twitch space combat inside black holes .

Last but not least is the element of random events. Sometimes you pilot can get a sickness and then you will keep getting money each month as donations from organization fighting that disease.
Each time you play the game you may run into a different problem . Sometimes some of the big bosses can come to your system location and kill everyone , forcing you to flee and adapt new tactics .If you set game on hardest diffeculty you can actually loose entire galaxy to pirates & dominators .

It really is a solid game in all aspects . My only complain is that I prefered Dominatos (robots) as main story villains and not Pirates in this expansion . The pirate faction has some issues though because you might get a quest to protect all ships in pirate system which is kidna dumb because its just nearly impossible to do without some serious luck .

reviewText:
This game has a lot of good points and several not so good points. I recommend getting if it's on sale.

Pros
Lots to do (Missions, Trading, Text Quests, Planetary Battles)
Open World
Lots of upgrades
World feels alive
Can command a team of rangers
Piracy is fun
Pirate route is interesting

Cons
Lack of Player impact
Planetary battles quite weak
Text quests can be annoying
Fighting dominators can be a pain
Lack of options when investing in projects

Overall I have had a lot of fun with this game. I first played it back in 2006 when i read a review on some game site. While the game is fun with lots to do, it can be frustrating at times. You really can't affect the state of affairs in the galaxy. While you can invest in projects and purchase fleets and stations, these have little affect. If they had allowed you to build a fleet and have more control over building up the coalition and which systems to attack it would have been a much better game. Planetary battles are just not that fun, the play control and the design of the minigame is just a bad RTS. I just skip these, but unfortunately you lose out on a lot of potential income. Hopefully another similar game will be released that takes what is good about this game and gives it more options so the player can affect the game world more directly.
